entry.title: Episode 133: Introduction to Watir
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/133.png?1368380047!

Hillary Hueter demonstrates how to validate user interfaces with Watir. Learn how to write scripts that automate common functions (clicking links, selecting options from a list, filling out forms, etc.) and how to use Watir in Cucumber or RSpec tests.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/133_watir.m4v

entry.title: Episode 132: Intro to Ruby 2.0
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/132.png?1368379942!

Matt Aimonetti introduces the latest version of Ruby -- Ruby 2.0. Find out what's new in Ruby and what it means for your Rails applications.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/132_ruby.m4v

entry.title: Episode 131: Profiling Ruby
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/131.png?1366730508!

Greg Price was frustrated by how long it takes Ruby 1.9.3 apps to launch, so he decided to dive in and fix things. By using general techniques for profiling and fixing code, he was able to make app launching in Ruby 2.0 twice as fast. Greg shares his techniques and shows how they can be used for any performance problem in MRI or a C extension.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/131_profiling.m4v

entry.title: Episode 130: What's New in Rails 4
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/130.png?1360522340!

Ruby on Rails 4 offers a number of useful new features and also breaks ties with a lot of old Rails baggage. Ben Hughes talks about what's new in the next release of Rails and shows how to prepare your existing Rails 3 apps for the upgrade.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/130_rails4.m4v

entry.title: Episode 129: Class's Class is Class (Metaprogramming is Trolling You)
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/129.png?1356811061!

Chris Kelly returns to SD Ruby to give a talk on Ruby metaprogramming, starting with the Ruby Object Model and working through the most common metaprogramming callbacks.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/129_class.m4v

entry.title: Episode 128: Writing APIs
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/128.png?1356810791!

James Miller explores writing and testing JSON APIs with Sinatra and rack/test. Authenticate, handle errors, set proper HTTP status codes, customize headers with pagination and rate limiting data, and mount it to an existing Rails app.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/128writingapis.m4v

entry.title: Episode 127: Saying No to NoSQL
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/127.png?1356042011!

Jonathan Neddenriep shows how to migrate a production application from MongoDB to Postgres without losing your mind or your data.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/127_justsayno.m4v

entry.title: Episode 126: Fast
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/126.png?1347031684!

We live in a fast society, so why should our apps be any different? Richard Schneeman from Heroku demonstrates how to optimize your Rails app for speed and scalability -- on both the front end and back end. If you wanna go fast, this talk is for you.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/126_fast.m4v

entry.title: Episode 125: Get Concurrent With Puma
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/125.png?1346005949!

Matt Aimonetti shows how to serve up web pages using Puma, a multithreaded, easy-to-use Ruby web server. Based on Mongrel, Puma is a small library built with Rack that provides a very fast and concurrent HTTP 1.1 server for Ruby web applications.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/125_puma.m4v

entry.title: Episode 124: Build Your Api With Node.js
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/124.png?1346005917!

Scott Motte demonstrates how to build an API for your next web application using the power of Node.js.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/124_node.m4v

entry.title: Episode 123: A Tour of Haskell: A Rubyist's Take on Functional Programming
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/123.png?1346005887!

Xavier Lange discusses features and concepts of Haskell. Haskell is a high-level, strictly-typed, and lazy functional programming language. This talk is geared towards Ruby developers who want to stretch their programming muscles.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/123_haskell.m4v

entry.title: Episode 122: RubyMotion: Native iOS Apps in Ruby
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/122.png?1346005849!

Learn how to get started with RubyMotion, a new tool that lets you quickly develop and test native iOS applications for iPhone or iPad using Ruby. James Miller demonstrates how to create a project, configure it, manage dependencies, and get your idea into the App Store.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/122_rubymotion.m4v

entry.title: Episode 121: How to Make Your Rails App Roar With the Power of Lion
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/121.png?1346005808!

OS X Lion might be the world's most advanced OS, but we don't normally use it to host Rails applications. It can be pricey, hard to virtualize, and doesn't work well with Linux-based servers. Patrick Crowley demonstrates a breakthrough way to integrate OS X services into your app.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/121_osx.m4v

entry.title: Episode 120: Postgres FTW: Postgres Is Just Easier
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/120.png?1346005767!

Why choose Postgres over the "other" open source database? Guyren Howe has the answer. He will demonstrate how Postgres can make building database applications easier -- including custom data types, custom functions, robust text search, and more.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/120_postgres.m4v

entry.title: Episode 119: Postgres Rules
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/119.png?1346005662!

Postgres has a powerful feature called rules that let you rewrite incoming queries. Rules are similar to triggers in Postgres, but much more efficient. Guyren Howe shows how to use rules in some common use cases.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/119_postgres.m4v

entry.title: Episode 118: Smaller Javascript Packages With the Rails Asset Pipeline
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/118.png?1346005597!

Marc Leglise shows how to break up your large application.js into logical chunks, leveraging more power from the Rails 3 asset pipeline. Building on last month's talk by Rafael Cardoso, this method allows you to separate concerns about download sizes from triggers for page-specific javascript.

Bonus content: download the slides and code from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/118_javascript.m4v

entry.title: Episode 117: Command Line Applications in Ruby: the Good Stuff
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/117.png?1346005558!

Mark Ranallo explores writing command line applications for the Unix programming environment, including a basic overview, some tips/tricks, and Ruby gems that can help.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/117_command.m4v

entry.title: Episode 116: Javascript Isolation With the Rails Asset Pipeline
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/116.png?1346005521!

Rafael Cardoso shows how to load page specific javascript, while still using the default configuration for the asset pipeline in Rails 3.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/116_javascript.m4v

entry.title: Episode 115: You're a Manager. Now What?
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/115.png?1346005425!

It happens to a lot of us: you're doing a good job as an engineer, you've been around the company for a while, and BAM! You get "promoted". Well, it turns out that like engineering, management takes skill and practice. You can't just expect that because you're smart you'll be good at it. Nic Benders from New Relic talks about what some of those skills are, and how to work on improving them.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/115_manager.m4v

entry.title: Episode 114: The Global Interpeter Lock in Ruby, Python, and Javascript
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/114.png?1346005371!

Have you heard of the infamous Global Interpreter Lock that prevents Ruby from being webscale? Are you so scared you might switch to Node.js? Well, before you do, learn more about what the GIL is, what it does, and why it isn't being removed. Matt Aimonetti explains.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/114_global.m4v

entry.title: Episode 113: Visualize Twitter #tags in Real Time
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/113.png?1342552326!

Etienne de Bruin demonstrates how to visualize Twitter retweets in real time using the tweetstream gem, arbor.js, Redis, and Resque. He also shares his personal journey as a developer and how he came to love Ruby.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/113_twitter.m4v

entry.title: Episode 112: Ultra-Minimalist Gem Bootstrapping
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/112.png?1341853860!

The simplest way to start a gem from scratch is using nothing but your bare hands. And Bundler. Ian Young shows us how.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/112_gems.m4v

entry.title: Episode 111: Ruby Debugging: Life After "Puts"
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/111.png?1341506738!

Have you outgrown basic debugging in Ruby? Rob Kaufman shows how to step up your game and use the Ruby debugger in a variety of practical ways.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/111rubydebugger.m4v

entry.title: Episode 110: Converting Flat Data into Rich Ruby Objects with :composed_of
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/110.png?1340647698!

Storing simple data as model attributes in a database is easy to do in Rails, but sometimes we want to handle and manipulate data that is more than just a string or a number.The :composed_of macro in ActiveRecord gives us that ability, and it's simpler than you think. Chris McCann shows us how.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/110composedof.m4v

entry.title: Episode 109: Transforming Ruby Code
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/109.png?1334787957!

Programmatically transforming Ruby code is easier than you think and has several interesting applications: automated refactoring, coding style/best practices enforcement, DSL translation, and more. Ben Hughes explores how to transform ruby code with available tools.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/109_transform.m4v

entry.title: Episode 108: Fog: The Ruby Cloud Services Library
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/108.png?1334774910!

James Miller demonstrates how to get up and running with Fog, including practical use cases, caveats, and how to make Fog better by contributing back.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/108_fog.m4v

entry.title: Episode 107: Advanced Heroku with the Celadon Cedar Stack
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/107.png?1316447751!

Ryan Daigle and Blake Gentry explore all the new features in Heroku's Celadon Cedar stack.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/107_heroku.m4v

entry.title: Episode 106: JRuby: Ruby in the JVM. Why on Earth?!?
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/106.png?1310833271!

JRuby is a 100% pure-Java implementation of Ruby with high performance, real threading, and a vast array of libraries. Chris McCann explores how JRuby can provide real value for Rails developers.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/106_jruby.m4v

entry.title: Episode 105: Get Your Flow On: Mastering Your Development Workflow
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/105.png?1311900690!

Rob Kaufman explores tools and options for improving your development process: common issues with managing tasks, starting work, committing branches, and getting completed tasks verified and deployed to production. It's all about automating the little steps because details are too easy to forget.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/105toolsharpening.m4v

entry.title: Episode 104: Send SMS Messages and Make Phone Calls From Your App With Twilio
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/104.png?1311900709!

Brian Levine shows how easy it is to add phone services to your application using Twilio. Twilio wraps powerful telecom infrastructure with a simple REST API and offers pay-as-you-go pricing with cloud scalability.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/104_twilio.m4v

entry.title: Episode 103: HTML5 Quick Start with Compass-html5-boilerplate
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/103.png?1299461057!

Peter Gumeson shows off his compass-html5-boilerplate gem, which uses Compass to make it easier to integrate the HTML5 Boilerplate template into Rails apps.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/103compasshtml5_boilerplate.m4v

entry.title: Episode 102: Newick-Ruby: A Gem for Manipulating Newick Format Trees
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/102.png?1299460973!

Jonathan Badger explores Newick format trees, and how to manipulate them using his Newick-ruby gem.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/102_newick.m4v

entry.title: Episode 101: TRegexp: Friendly Regular Expressions
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/101.png?1299460926!

Ian Young introduces his first gem, a human-friendly DSL for regular expressions.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/101_tregexp.m4v

entry.title: Episode 100: Getting Oriented with Compass
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/100.png?1299377041!

Patrick Crowley shows how to turbo-charge your layouts with Compass, a lightweight stylesheet framework built on top of Haml and Sass.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/100_compass.m4v

entry.title: Episode 099: Omniauth: Future Proof Your Authentication
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/99.png?1299460567!

Kevin Ball shows how the traditional model of username/password authentication is dying, and how Omniauth makes it all rainbows and sunshine going forward.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/099_omniauth.m4v

entry.title: Episode 098: Give Yourself Some Backbone
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/98.png?1299376972!

Ryan Weald gives a brief overview of Backbone.js and the advantages it has for your project.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/098_backbone.m4v

entry.title: Episode 097: Basic Reporting with Ruby and CouchDB
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/97.png?1299376937!

Christopher Petersen shows how to create both basic reports on individual user behavior and aggregate reports across all user activity.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/097_couchdb.m4v

entry.title: Episode 096: Rounded Corners Everywhere
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/96.png?1299376892!

Scott Olmsted explores Javascript libraries to simulate CSS3 decorations on browsers that don't support them. (Yeah, we're talking about you Internet Explorer.)

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/096_rounded.m4v

entry.title: Episode 095: The State of MacRuby
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/95.png?1299374363!

Matt Aimonetti discusses the latest developments with the MacRuby project, which aims to implement Ruby 1.9 directly on top of Mac OS X core technologies.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/095_macruby.m4v

entry.title: Episode 094: Refactoring ActiveRecord Models
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/94.png?1299373810!

It's always important to keep your ActiveRecord models in tip-top shape. Ben Hughes explores several techniques for refactoring models and preventing them from getting out of hand.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/094refactoringmodels.m4v

entry.title: Episode 093: Are You Redis?
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/93.png?1297180702!

Emanuele Tozzato gives a brief introduction to Redis, then demonstrates real-life database performance optimization with redis-object and how to manage background jobs using Resque.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/093_redis.m4v

entry.title: Episode 092: File Uploads With S3SwfUpload
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/92.png?1297273018!

Nathan Colgate Clark gives a general overview of his Amazon S3 upload plugin (past, present, and future) and shares his thoughts on how it managed to stand out on GitHub.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/092_upload.m4v

entry.title: Episode 091: Message Block
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/91.png?1297180648!

Ben Hughes shows off message_block, a gem which simplifies generating flash and error messages. Additionally, Ben discusses how to test gem development using Cucumber and Cukigem.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/091_messageblock.m4v

entry.title: Episode 090: CoffeeScript
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/90.png?1297273134!

People are drawn to Ruby by its beautiful syntax, and CoffeeScript brings that same joie de vivre to Javascript. John Lynch shares his experience using CoffeeScript for both web and mobile app development.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/090_coffeescript.m4v

entry.title: Episode 089: Ruleby
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/89.png?1297271650!

Chris McCann demonstrates Ruleby, a Ruby implementation of a rules engine based on the Rete algorithm.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/089_ruleby.m4v

entry.title: Episode 088: Trucker
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/88.png?1297180549!

Patrick Crowley talks about Trucker, a new gem that makes it easier to migrate legacy data into Rails apps.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/088_trucker.m4v

entry.title: Episode 087: Searching With Solr
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/87.png?1297287316!

Get up and running in no time with enterprise-grade search powered by Solr. Nick Zadrozny shows you what Solr can do, how it works, and how you can make the most of it in production.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/087_solr.m4v

entry.title: Episode 086: Mobile Web Apps Using jQTouch
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/86.png?1297180488!

Patrick Crowley dives into the world of mobile app development and shows how to use the jQTouch framework to quickly build awesome mobile-optimized web apps.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/086_mobile.m4v

entry.title: Episode 085: Introduction to Node.js
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/85.png?1297180458!

Web standards advocate Edward O'Connor gives a quick introduction to Node.js, a new event-driven networking engine for JavaScript.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/085_node.m4v

entry.title: Episode 084: Quick and Cheap Usability for Programmers
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/84.png?1297180390!

Megan O'Rorke introduces the general concept and goal of usability, and shares some quick and cheap usability resources for Ruby developers.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/084_usability.m4v

entry.title: Episode 083: Testing Philosophies
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/83.png?1297180355!

Rob Kaufman discusses common testing philosophies and methodologies in use by the Ruby community.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/083_testing.m4v

entry.title: Episode 082: Behavior Driven Development Using Ruby, Cucumber, and rSpec
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/82.png?1297367446!

Steve Ross gives an introduction to behavior driven development using Ruby, Cucumber, and rSpec. This is a practical how-to for developers who have not yet integrated behavior driven development into their workflow.

Bonus content: download slides and view notes from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/082_bdd.m4v

entry.title: Episode 081: Rolling with Riak
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/81.png?1275694882!

John Lynch from Rigel Group gives an overview of Riak, the newest kid on the NoSQL block, and explains why it should power your next web-scale app.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/081_riak.m4v

entry.title: Episode 080: EventMachine, AMQP, and WebSockets: The Musical
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/80.png?1274895968!

Dan Simpson and Nick Zadrozny give an overview of cutting-edge, real-time programming for the web; and demonstrate an interactive, web-based sequencer.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/080_musical.m4v

entry.title: Episode 079: Artificial Stupidity: Adding Smarts to Yer Kode
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/79.png?1272132777!

Machine learning and data mining have long been "black arts" because they require access to expensive computing clusters. Randall Thomas discusses machine learning and the problem spaces it can help solve.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/079_machine.m4v

entry.title: Episode 078: Scripting Android With Ruby
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/78.png?1269011170!

Mark Ranallo will give an introduction to using JRuby in conjunction with the Android Scripting Environment.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/078_android.m4v

entry.title: Episode 077: Building Your Own Hosting Environment
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/77.png?1265049703!

Nic Benders will show you what's needed for building a hosting environment for production applications. The focus will be on selecting server hardware, picking a Linux Distro, and getting your Rails app running.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/077_building.m4v

entry.title: Episode 076: OpenCyc
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/76.png?1264463598!

Guyren Howe gives a way-too-brief demonstration of OpenCyc, an AI technology based on the world's most comprehensive general-purpose ontology. Along the way, he reveals how to talk to OpenCyc using JRuby.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/076_opencyc.m4v

entry.title: Episode 075: Heroku
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/75.png?1263841546!

Blake Mizerany from Heroku shows off the company's cloud platform for Ruby applications. The talk covers Heroku basics, Sinatra, Ruby development, and scaling.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/075_heroku.m4v

entry.title: Episode 074: Moonshine: 190 Proof Deployment
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/74.png?1263230377!

Jarin Udom shows how to set up a full Rails stack and deploy your app on a bare Ubuntu server in 10 minutes. Is he drunk? Find out!

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/074_moonshine.m4v

entry.title: Episode 073: Cappuccino
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/73.png?1262709648!

Cappuccino is a framework for building desktop-caliber applications that run in a web browser. Brian Chapados reviews the design concepts of Cappuccino and the underlying Objective-J language, shows how to get started, and builds a simple app for searching scientific literature databases.

This talk was part of the DjangoSD/SD Ruby mashup meeting.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/073_cappuccino.m4v

entry.title: Episode 072: MongoDB
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/72.png?1262027446!

Scott Motte introduces us to the document-oriented database MongoDB and shows how to use MongoDB as an alternative to MySQL and ActiveRecord using the MongoMapper gem.

This talk was part of the DjangoSD/SD Ruby mashup meeting.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/072_mongo.m4v

entry.title: Episode 071: Mess of Protocols
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/71.png?1261156586!

Guyren Howe discusses how we use different applications and protocols to govern how we communicate: with whom, how privately, how immediately, whether through text/video/whatever, and so on. He proposes we decouple these ideas, which would simplify and enrich the ways we communicate.

This talk was part of the DjangoSD/SD Ruby mashup meeting.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/071_messofprotocols.m4v

entry.title: Episode 070: Processing Real-world HTML
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/70.png?1260810099!

Edward O'Connor from djangosd gives an overview of html5lib, a major-desktop-browser-compatible HTML parser and tokenizer for both Ruby and Python.

This talk was part of the DjangoSD/SD Ruby mashup meeting.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/070_html5lib.m4v

entry.title: Episode 069: Rails 3: From Vaporware to Awesomeness in 12 Months
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/69.png?1259966961!

Yehuda Katz returns to San Diego with a report on the latest developments with the Ruby on Rails web application framework.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/069_rails.m4v

entry.title: Episode 068: Hybrid iPhone Apps with Titanium Mobile
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/68.png?1259597435!

Scott Motte talks about iPhone development using the Titanium Mobile framework, including how to build a basic app.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/068_titanium.m4v

entry.title: Episode 067: Cooking up a Cloud (with Chef & EC2)
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/67.png?1258745212!

Chef is a young and ambitious Ruby DSL built for easy configuration management. Nick Zadrozny will take a look at the philosophy of configuration management, the basics of Chef, and some recipes to build out a basic Rails server.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/067_chef.m4v

entry.title: Episode 066: Unit Testing: The Easy Way
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/66.png?1258137619!

With Rspec and Cucumber, Ruby has brought testing to a whole new level, but tests still require a lot of work.

But things just got better. Llewellyn Falco will show you new patterns and practices to dramatically decrease the amount of effort needed to test.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/066_testing.m4v

entry.title: Episode 065: HotRuby + jQuery: Ruby in the Browser
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/65.png?1257785173!

Daniel Moore will demonstrate using the HotRuby VM to execute Ruby code natively in the browser. The demonstration shows how Ruby can call native JS libraries, like jQuery, to perform DOM manipulation.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/065_hotruby.m4v

entry.title: Episode 064: Ruby 1.9.1
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/64.png?1242953494!

Bradly Feeley reviews the new features and syntax changes in the latest production ready Ruby release, Ruby 1.9.1.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/064_ruby191.m4v

entry.title: Episode 063: Earning an "A" in YSlow
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/63.png?1242953407!

Nick Zadrozny takes us on a tour of basic website performance optimization, covering 13 optimizations you shouldn't deploy your site without. He'll also go over some sample implementations for a typical Rails app, including a demo of how to serve your public assets from Amazon's new CloudFront CDN.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/063_yslow.m4v

entry.title: Episode 062: Track Magic
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/62.png?1242953303!

Jim Rea will demonstrate Track Magic, a plugin for Panorama that allows Rails developers to interact directly with Rails databases on the desktop without a browser.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/062_trackmagic.m4v

entry.title: Episode 061: Tanning Bed
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/61.png?1242952972!

Rob Kaufman demonstrates Tanning Bed, his new Solr search mixin for any Ruby class. Tanning Bed makes fewer assumptions about how you want to deal with the Solr search engine, while still providing easy Ruby-like interfaces.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/061_tanningbed.m4v

entry.title: Episode 060: Migrating Legacy Data
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/60.png?1242792928!

Let's face it. Migrating legacy data into a new app is a giant pain in the ass. It's slow, error prone, and a ton of work.

What if you could import old data into a new app before it's finished? Normalize fields? Clean up old data? And migrate often? Patrick Crowley shows the way.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/060_legacy.m4v

entry.title: Episode 059: Rails Case Study
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/59.png?1242791813!

Guyren Howe is doing something a little different with his current project, trying to make it more user-modifiable and user friendly than your average intraweb application, and removing some of the redundancy in regular Rails code. The current state of the project will be discussed, along with whether the interesting parts should be open sourced.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/059_casestudy.m4v

entry.title: Episode 058: MacRuby: What's the big deal?
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/58.png?1242790820!

Last year, Apple released MacRuby, an open source Ruby implementation written on top of the Objective-C runtime. Writing native MacOSX applications in Ruby without having to pay the cost of using a bridge is now a reality. This is an important milestone for Ruby, Apple and the Ruby community.

Matt Aimonetti will explain the implementation, show how to build desktop applications with MacRuby and HotCocoa, and discuss why Ruby developers should add this new tool to their utility belt. Matt will also talk about the future of MacRuby.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/058_macruby.m4v

entry.title: Episode 057: Facebooker Plugin
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/57.png?1242789673!

Michael Madrid discusses Styleact (a Facebook application) and how to develop Facebook apps using Ruby on Rails and the Facebooker plugin.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/057_facebook.m4v

entry.title: Episode 056: Ruby 1.9 or Bust!
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/56.png?1240852816!

Rob Kaufman talks about his new Ruby 1.9 or Bust project. The project is dedicated to updating popular Ruby gems to be Ruby 1.9 compatible, and is seeking donations to hire a full-time developer to work on porting gems.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/056_ruby19.m4v

entry.title: Episode 055: MySQL, Postgres, and Rails
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/55.png?1236986586!

Guyren Howe has considerable experience with both MySQL and PostgreSQL. He discusses the myriad technical and other advantages to using PostgreSQL instead of MySQL for, well, pretty much anything.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/055_postgres.m4v

entry.title: Episode 054: Paperclip
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/54.png?1236986586!

Patrick Crowley talks about Paperclip, a lightweight plugin for handling attachments.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/054_paperclip.m4v

entry.title: Episode 053: Ruby Arduino Development (RAD)
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/53.png?1236986586!

Sensors and servos in hand, JD Barnhart shows off the current state of RAD, the Rails inspired framework bringing convention over configuration and Ruby sensibility to the Arduino Physical computing platform.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/053_rad.m4v

entry.title: Episode 052: Shadow
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/52.png?1236986585!

Jordan Fowler reveals his new Shadow plugin that tracks attribute and association changes to ActiveRecord objects, making it easy to create activity feeds for your application.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/052_shadow.m4v

entry.title: Episode 051: Archaeopteryx
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/51.png?1236986585!

Giles Bowkett shows off his mega-cool MIDI scaffolding generator for creating dance music with Ruby.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/051_archaeopteryx.m4v

entry.title: Episode 050: One-man Lightning Talk
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/50.png?1236986584!

Kevin Clark is back again and talking about his latest work: Rubinius, grammar parsing from ruby, kqueue, and massive build systems.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/050_kfc.m4v

entry.title: Episode 049: Intro to EC2
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/49.png?1236986584!

Chris Petersen gives an introduction to working with Amazon EC2, and discusses the advantages and disadvantage to hosting your Ruby applications there.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/049_ec2.m4v

entry.title: Episode 048: Ruby for Data Processing
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/48.png?1236986583!

Brian Chapados talks about using ruby and rake to build a simple workflow to coordinate external processes.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/048rubyfor_data.m4v

entry.title: Episode 047: Lazy Indexing
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/47.png?1236986583!

Matt Aimonetti shows how to quickly get your database queries to run faster when you are not a DBA and are running out of time.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/047_indexing.m4v

entry.title: Episode 046: RSpec in 15 minutes
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/46.png?1236986582!

Cliff Rhyne describes in 15 minutes what it takes to get up and running with RSpec.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/046_rspec.m4v

entry.title: Episode 045: Merb
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/45.png?1236986582!

Much like Rails, Merb is a MVC web-framework written in Ruby. In this talk, Jordan Fowler introduces Merb and presents some of the distinctions and tradeoffs between the two frameworks.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/045_merb.m4v

entry.title: Episode 044: Ext JavaScript Library
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/44.png?1236986581!

Adam Grant talks about his experiences using Ext, a new Javascript library for creating advanced UI controls (like grids, trees, progress bars, etc).

http://video.sdruby.org/video/044extjavascript.m4v

entry.title: Episode 043: Facebook API
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/43.png?1236986581!

John Bresnik discusses the ruby library for the Facebook API, Facebooker, based on his production experience building Facebook applications. Presentation includes general overview of the Facebook API, Facebooker specifics, as well as code examples.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/043_facebooker.m4v

entry.title: Episode 042: Deploying Rails on Slicehost
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/42.png?1236986580!

Jared Kuolt shows how to quickly deploy your Rails application to a Slicehost VPS. This talk covers installing MySQL, Nginx, Rails and Mongrel, as well as deployment using Capistrano.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/042_slicehost.m4v

entry.title: Episode 041: MySQL Clustering
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/41.png?1236986578!

Rob Kaufman takes on database scaling with MySQL. This talk will walk you through setting up a Master (read write) Slave (read only) MySQL network, as well as a Master Master, or Multi-Master network. The talk will also cover the whys and when of database clustering.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/041_mysql.m4v

entry.title: Episode 040: Unobtrusive Javascript
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/40.png?1236986578!

Matt Aimonetti lays down the law on best-practice Ajax, using behavior oriented javascript with progressive enhancement.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/040_unobtrusive.m4v

entry.title: Episode 039: ActionMailer in Action
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/39.png?1236986578!

Rob Kaufman talks about using ActionMailer safely, how to keep out of the spam box and how to test your emails before your customers see them.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/039_actionmailer.m4v

entry.title: Episode 038: Haml and Sass in 15 minutes
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/38.png?1236986577!

Patrick Crowley gets you up to speed on using Haml and Sass. Haml is a drop in replacement for ERB that turns your views into beautiful code poetry. Sass does the same for CSS.

Bonus content: download the slides from this talk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/038hamlsass.m4v

entry.title: Episode 037: Rails Sexy Charts
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/37.png?1236986577!

Matt Aimonetti demonstrates how to create awesome, Flash-powered charts by integrating Rails with amCharts.

Bonus content: download the sample app shown in this talk or read Matt's original Sexy charts in less than 5 minutes blog post.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/037sexycharts.m4v

entry.title: Episode 036: The Return of Kevin Clark
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/36.png?1236986576!

Kevin Clark takes a break from Powerset to give a full-throttle talk on using Merb as a JSON-RPC service, god, gem2rpm, and heckle.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/036_god.m4v

entry.title: Episode 035: ActiveRecord Backup & MimetypeFu
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/35.png?1236986576!

Matt Aimonetti demonstrates his newest plugins: ActiveRecord Backup and MimetypeFu.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/035_railsplugins.m4v

entry.title: Episode 034: Intro to JRuby
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/34.png?1236986575!

Brian Chapados shows how to install and work with the latest JRuby release.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/034_jruby.m4v

entry.title: Episode 033: Life on Edge
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/33.png?1236986575!

If you're a Rails junkie, you'll want to develop on Edge Rails. Matt Clark explains how to get started and shares some of the challenges of working on Edge.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/033_edgerails.m4v

entry.title: Episode 032: Capistrano
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/32.png?1236986574!

Rob Kaufman takes on Capistrano 2. What is it? How does it work? What's changed since version 1?

http://video.sdruby.org/video/032_capistrano.m4v

entry.title: Episode 031: Seaside
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/31.png?1236986574!

Roger Whitney explores Seaside, the web application framework based on Smalltalk.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/031_seaside.m4v

entry.title: Episode 030: Tuneshelf
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/30.png?1236986573!

Dominic Damian talks about his experiences building Tuneshelf, a web application that allows music fans to keep track of their favorite music albums.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/030_tuneshelf.m4v

entry.title: Episode 029: Big Stinking Piles (of data)
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/29.png?1236986572!

What do you do when third-party data vendors don't speak REST? Rob Kaufman discuss real-world techniques for importing and exporting data. (This talk was also given at RailsConf 2007.)

http://video.sdruby.org/video/029_stinking.m4v

entry.title: Episode 028: Simple Sidebar Plugin
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/28.png?1236986572!

Ryan Felton shows how to use Simple Sidebar plugin to DRY up sidebar content in applications.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/028_sidebars.m4v

entry.title: Episode 027: Headliner and Styler
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/27.png?1236986571!

Patrick Crowley talks about his newest plugins: Headliner and Styler.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/027headlinerstyler.m4v

entry.title: Episode 026: ActsAsSolr
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/26.png?1236986571!

Rob Kaufman shows how easy it is to integrate Solr powered search into your Rails application using the ActsAsSolr plugin.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/026actsas_solr.m4v

entry.title: Episode 025: Ajax CSS Star Rating with ActsAsRateable
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/25.png?1236986570!

Ryan Felton shows off how to build an Ajax-powered, CSS star rater using the ActsAsRateable plugin and Komodo Media's CSS Star Rating Redux technique.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/025ajaxrating.m4v

entry.title: Episode 024: Using Ruby + Amazon SQS to build backdoors
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/24.png?1236986570!

Brian Chapados talks about using Ruby and Amazon's Simple Que Service web service to build backdoors into systems.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/024amazonsqs.m4v

entry.title: Episode 023: RubyInline
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/23.png?1236986569!

Nick Zadrozny shows us how to use C in Ruby with RubyInline. As an example, Nick walks us through writing a password-generating application with the help of Diceware.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/023rubyinline.m4v

entry.title: Episode 022: DRP
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/22.png?1236986568!

DRP stands for Directed Ruby Programming. In this episode, Warren Henning explains exactly what that means and why you might be interested in it.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/022_drp.m4v

entry.title: Episode 021: Merb
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/21.png?1236986567!

Chris Van Pelt gives us an introduction to Merb. Merb is a Ruby framework built by Ezra Zygmuntowicz.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/021_merb.m4v

entry.title: Episode 020: ImageScience
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/20.png?1236986566!

In this episode, Tom Werner covers some of the basics of the ruby image library ImageScience. ImageScience is a wrapper for the FreeImage graphics library, and is a lightweight alternative to RMagick.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/020_imagescience.mp4

entry.title: Episode 019: AWS S3
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/19.png?1236986565!

Jordan Fowler gives a presentation on Amazon's S3 service. He also covers the AWS::S3 gem written by Marcel Molina Jr.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/019awss3.m4v

entry.title: Episode 018: StaffTool
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/18.png?1236986565!

In this episode, Toby Sterrett gives us an update on his soon-to-be-released project StaffTool. StaffTool is a web-based church management application build with Ruby on Rails.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/018_stafftool.m4v

entry.title: Episode 017: ActsNaked
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/17.png?1236986563!

In today's episode, Patrick Crowley introduces his first Rails plugin titled ActsNaked. It's an easy way to strip your models and keep them DRY.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/017_actsnaked.m4v

entry.title: Episode 016: MasterView Templates
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/16.png?1236986563!

Deb Lewis showcases her project MasterView. MasterView is a template language for Rails.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/016masterview.mp4

entry.title: Episode 015: Rails for Legacy Applications
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/15.png?1236986562!

Patrick Crowley covers some of the finer point of using Rails with legacy applications.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/015railsforlegacyapps.mp4

entry.title: Episode 014: Ruby Idioms - Part 1
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/14.png?1236986562!

Tom Werner gives us part 1 of his series on Ruby idoms.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/014rubyidioms_1.mp4

entry.title: Episode 013: Mocha and Stubba
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/13.png?1236986561!

Kevin Clark shows us how to use mocks and stubs in your Ruby tests using Mocha and Stubba

http://video.sdruby.org/video/013mochastubba.m4v

entry.title: Episode 012: Deployment
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/12.png?1236986560!

Dominic Damian talks about the different options available to you when deploying a Rails application. He covers areas such as servers, caching, database, and hosting.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/012_deployment.m4v

entry.title: Episode 011: ActsAsTaggable Plugin
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/11.png?1236986560!

Patrick Crowley discusses his experiences with actsastaggable. He starts off outlining some of the differences between the gem and the plugin. Patrick then creates a simple app to show off some of the capabilities of the plugin.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/011actsas_taggable.m4v

entry.title: Episode 010: REST Web Services with Rails
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/10.png?1236986559!

Chris Abad talks a little bit about providing web services to your Rails application using some of the new REST features found in Edge Rails. At the end, he also throws in a bonus tip on using Rick Olson's authentication plugin restful_authentication to add authentication to your REST API.

Here are the slides

http://video.sdruby.org/video/010rest2.m4v

entry.title: Episode 009: REST with Rails
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/9.png?1236986559!

In this episode, Kevin Clark shows us some of the new REST features found in Edge Rails. He covers some basic concepts such as HTTP verbs, and also takes a look at using RESTful routes.

Here are the slides

http://video.sdruby.org/video/009_rest.m4v

entry.title: Episode 008: Chronic
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/8.png?1236986558!

Tom Werner has released the ruby gem Chronic, a natural language date and time parser. In this episode he gives us a quick run through of some of the cool points.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/008_chronic.m4v

entry.title: Episode 007: Rails Authentication
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/7.png?1236986557!

Kevin Clark gives us a brief overview of two of Rick Olson's authentication plugins: actsasauthenticated and restful_authentication.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/007_authentication.m4v

entry.title: Episode 006: Dynamic Domains
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/6.png?1236986556!

Chris Abad introduces the new web service, Outlandish. He also shows us how they handle dynamic domains within Outlandish.

Here are the slides

http://video.sdruby.org/video/006dynamicdomains.m4v

entry.title: Episode 005: ARTS Plugin
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/5.png?1236986556!

Kevin Clark demos his new Rails plugin, ARTS, which allows you to test your RJS templates.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/005_arts.m4v

entry.title: Episode 004: Numbers
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/4.png?1236986556!

Tom Werner wows us with the power of numbers in Ruby.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/004_numbers.m4v

entry.title: Episode 003: mkmf
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/3.png?1236986555!

Kevin Clark takes us through some of the work he's doing on mkmf for his Google Summer of Code project. We also get a quick preview of Kevin's RailsDay app, Advisr.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/003_mkmf.m4v

entry.title: Episode 002: Camping
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/2.png?1236986555!

Chris Van Pelt discussing Camping, a microframework built by Why the Lucky Stiff. Chris also gives us a preview of a cool little Camping app he built title Croppr.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/002_camping.m4v

entry.title: Episode 001: Summer of Rails
entry.content:
!http://sdruby.orghttp://s3.amazonaws.com/sdruby/screenshots/large/1.png?1236986551!

Patrick Crowley discusses Summer of Rails. He also introduces his first Summer of Rails project, Graffletopia.

http://video.sdruby.org/video/001summerof_rails.m4v
